item.title: Stock Buyers Wade Back In to Fuel Bounce From Lows: Markets Wrap
item.description: A renewed wave of dip buying fueled a rebound in stocks from session lows, with traders trying to look past the US downgrade by Moody’s Ratings that has sent bond yields climbing and weakened the US dollar.
item.dc:creator: Rita Nazareth

item.title: Five Key Charts to Watch in Global Commodities This Week
item.description: The scrap copper industry in the US is hustling to move piled up supplies over to China now that the two superpowers have put their trade dispute on a temporary pause. South Korea’s homegrown atomic technology has the world’s attention. And, US Health Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr.’s desire for diet changes has the potential to impact the global food supply chain.
item.dc:creator: Yvonne Yue Li, Nathan Risser, Heesu Lee, Will Wade

media:content.media:description: Customers refuel at a Love's gas station in Dallas, Texas, US, on Wednesday, May 7, 2025. Oil has trended lower since late January due to escalating trade frictions and plans by OPEC+ to keep boosting idled supply, but prices have moved away from their lows in the last couple of days.

item.title: Gold Gains as Dollar Slides Following Moody’s US Downgrade
item.description: Gold rose as the dollar tumbled after Moody’s Ratings stripped the US of its last top credit rating due to ballooning debt and deficits.
item.dc:creator: Yihui Xie, Jack Ryan

media:content.media:description: Gold bars. Photographer: Alessia Pierdomenico/Bloomberg

item.title: Millstein on US Downgrade, Tariffs, Trump Tax Bill
item.description: Jim Millstein, former US Treasury chief restructuring officer and Guggenheim Securities co-chairman, talks about Moody's downgrading the US credit rating, Republicans trying to push through President Donald Trump's tax and spending package and the impact of Trump's trade war on the economy. He's on "Bloomberg Open Interest." (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: S&P 500 Pares Drop as Dip Buyers Step In Following Moody’s Cut
item.description: US stocks edged lower on Monday and Treasury yields rose as a downgrade from Moody’s Ratings on the US government’s credit score renewed pressure on American assets.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Semenova

media:content.media:description: Traders work on the floor at the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York, US, on Thursday, May 15, 2025. US stocks were on pace to snap a three-day winning streak Thursday, driven by declines in technology, energy and retailers as traders assessed a slew of mixed economic figures.

item.title: Galipolo Vow on Higher-for-Longer Brazilian Rates Boosts Bets on Cycle’s End
item.description: Central bank President Gabriel Galípolo said Brazil needs interest rates to remain at a very restrictive level for longer, boosting investors’ bets that policymakers could stop the current tightening cycle at their next meeting in June.
item.dc:creator: Martha Viotti Beck, Andre Loureiro Dias

media:content.media:description: Gabriel Galipolo, governor of the Central Bank of Brazil, at the National Congress in Brasilia, Brazil, on Tuesday, April 8, 2025. Galipolo is meeting with the Senate to discuss the ability to track irregular transactions, the possibility of implementing specific records for resource transfers involving the online gaming sector, and the assessment of the economic impact of betting on the financial system.

item.title: Solar Shares Fall as GOP Targets Earlier End to Tax Credits
item.description: Shares of solar companies slumped after conservative Republican lawmakers said they had secured a commitment from leadership to end key clean-energy tax credits earlier than planned, part of a sweeping deal aimed at allowing President Donald Trump’s giant tax and spending package to advance.
item.dc:creator: Ari Natter, Will Wade

media:content.media:description: Contractors install SunRun Inc. solar panels on the roof of a new home at the Westline Homes Willowood Cottages community in Sacramento, California, U.S., on Wednesday, Aug. 15, 2018. California is the first state in the U.S. to require solar panels on almost all new homes as part of a mandate to take effect in 2020.

item.title: Ghana at Loggerheads With Afreximbank Over $768 Million Debt
item.description: Ghana, emerging from a bruising debt restructuring process, faces a dispute with African Export-Import Bank, one of its biggest commercial creditors, over whether it should take losses on a $768.4 million liability.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Hill, Ekow Dontoh

media:content.media:description: Cassiel Ato Forson

item.title: JPMorgan Sees High-Grade Debt Demand Up After US Cut
item.description: High-grade corporate bonds are likely to grow more attractive to fund managers as bond yields are pushed higher following the US losing its last top credit grading, according to JPMorgan Chase & Co.
item.dc:creator: Caleb Mutua

media:content.media:description: A Wall Street sign near the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York, US, on Monday, April 21, 2025. US stocks tumbled as President Donald Trump continued to verbally attack Jerome Powell, calling on the Federal Reserve chair to cut rates as signs mount the president's trade war is pushing the economy toward recession. Photographer: Michael Nagle/Bloomberg

item.title: JPMorgan Launches $500 Million Loan for FanDuel’s Snaitech Deal
item.description: JPMorgan Chase & Co. launched a $500 million leveraged loan to support FanDuel owner Flutter Entertainment Plc’s purchase of Playtech Plc’s Italian gambling business, according to a person with knowledge of the deal.
item.dc:creator: Rachel Graf, Jeannine Amodeo

media:content.media:description: UKRAINE - 2022/02/02: In this photo illustration, a Playtech plc logo of a gambling software development company is seen on a smartphone screen. (Photo Illustration by Pavlo Gonchar/SOPA Images/LightRocket via Getty Images)

item.title: A Step Toward Cheaper Medicine
item.description: President Trump signed an executive order to lower prescription drug prices in the US. The healthcare technology company Kalderos is working to simplify the complexities of the US drug system by working with manufacturers, healthcare providers and government agencies to ensure accurate pricing. Angie Franks, Kalderos CEO joined the C-Suite on Bloomberg Open Interest to talk about how her company is trying to make the US healthcare system more efficient. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: As the US Credit Rating Falls, Bankruptcy Fears Grow
item.description: Moody's stripped the US of its top credit rating, reinforcing Wall Street's concerns over a ballooning budget deficit. The move also sending ripples through corporate America as refinancing costs increase. Steve Zelin, Global Head of the Restructuring and Special Solutions Group at PJT Partners and a former chief restructuring officer at the US Treasury Department joined Wall Street Beat on Bloomberg Open Interest to talk about his concerns. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Treasuries, Dollar Fall as Moody’s Sharpens Focus on US Debt
item.description: Long-dated Treasuries fell on Monday as investor attention turned to the US’ ballooning debt after Moody’s Ratings stripped the nation of its last top credit rating.
item.dc:creator: Alice Atkins, Naomi Tajitsu

item.title: Mortgage Bonds Largely Unscathed After Moody’s Downgrade of US
item.description: Mortgage bonds supported by government-backed companies like Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac were trading slightly wider Monday morning after Moody’s Ratings downgraded the US late last week.
item.dc:creator: Scott Carpenter

media:content.media:description: Residential homes in Hercules, California, US, on Thursday, June 6, 2024. The Mortgage Bankers Association is scheduled to release mortgage applications figures on June 12.

item.title: Bloomberg Surveillance 05/19/2025
item.description: Jonathan Ferro, Lisa Abramowicz and Annmarie Hordern speak daily with leaders and decision makers from Wall Street to Washington and beyond. No other program better positions investors and executives for the trading day. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Novavax Soars After Covid Vaccine Secures Full FDA Approval
item.description: Novavax Inc. jumped as US regulators fully approved its Covid vaccine, easing investors’ concerns after the clearance was delayed and US Health and Human Services Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr. raised doubts about its efficacy.
item.dc:creator: Gerry Smith

media:content.media:description: A container of syringes used to administer Novavax Covid-19 vaccines

item.title: Republicans Risk Fiscal Disaster With Trump Tax Bill, Millstein Says
item.description: Jim Millstein, former US Treasury chief restructuring officer and Guggenheim Securities co-chairman, says Republicans and President Donald Trump are risking a "fiscal disaster" by trying to advance their tax and spending package. The GOP bill appears to increase the budget deficit, but when tariff revenues and federal employment cuts are added, the net fiscal impact is smaller and potentially deficit-neutral, according to Bloomberg Intelligence. Millstein is on "Bloomberg Open Interest." (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Equatorial Guinea Wins Rights to Islands in Dispute With Gabon
item.description: A top United Nations court ruled in favor of Equatorial Guinea in a long-running territorial dispute with Gabon, awarding it sovereignty over three small islands located in potentially oil-rich waters in the Gulf of Guinea.
item.dc:creator: Katarina Hoije, Kamailoudini Tagba

media:content.media:description: A fan of Equatorial Guinea's national football team rides a mini-bicycle on which he fixed his country's flag in the streets of Malabo on January 25, 2012 a few hours before the 2012 African Cup of Nations match between Equatorial Guinea and Senegal. AFP PHOTO / ALEXANDER JOE (Photo credit should read ALEXANDER JOE/AFP/Getty Images) Photographer: ALEXANDER JOE/AFP

item.title: Starmer’s Reset Hailed by EU Chiefs, Slammed by UK Conservatives
item.description: Keir Starmer sealed an agreement with European Union leaders that lays the ground for closer collaboration with the bloc, while revealing the political peril to Britain’s Prime Minister of revisiting the terms of Brexit.
item.dc:creator: Alberto Nardelli, Alex Wickham, Jorge Valero, Philip Aldrick

media:content.media:description: Antonio Costa, left, Keir Starmer, and Ursula von der Leyen on May 19. Photographer: Carl Court/Getty Images

item.title: About That Moody’s Downgrade
item.description: Tracy and Joe disagree
item.dc:creator: Joe Weisenthal, Tracy Alloway

media:content.media:description: Scott Bessent, US treasury secretary, during a House Financial Services Committee hearing in Washington, DC, US, on Wednesday, May 7, 2025. Bessent said he’s working with US legislators on outbound investment rules for China that would make clear what’s allowed and what’s not. Photographer: Pete Kiehart/Bloomberg

item.title: Nippon Steel Plans $14 Billion US Investment, Reuters Says
item.description: Nippon Steel Corp. plans to invest $14 billion in United States Steel Corp. if the Trump administration approves the merger of the companies, Reuters reported.
item.dc:creator: Simon Casey

media:content.media:description: The United States Steel Corp. Clairton Coke Works facility in Clairton, Pennsylvania, US, on Monday, Sept. 9, 2024. United States Steel Corp. faces the prospect of being broken apart and sold in parts if Nippon Steel Corp.'s $14.1 billion takeover fails.

item.title: Oil Fluctuates With Ukraine War Talks and US Outlook in Focus
item.description: Oil prices swung between small losses and gains as investors await details on talks to end the war in Ukraine and worries about demand persist following the downgrade of the US credit rating.
item.dc:creator: Alex Longley, Devika Krishna Kumar

media:content.media:description: Exxon Mobil Corp. oil drilling rigs near Stanton, Texas, US, on Saturday, March 15, 2025. The Permian Basin, a sprawling shale patch that lies beneath Texas and New Mexico, is North America's most prolific shale patch.

item.title: Lutnick Divests Cantor Stakes to His Children, 26North
item.description: US Commerce Secretary Howard Lutnick sold his stakes in Cantor Fitzgerald LP, the Wall Street business group he ran for more than three decades. Lutnick is passing ownership to his children and private outside investors. Todd Gillespie reports on Bloomberg Television.

item.title: Colombia Investors Look Past Fiscal Woes and Buy Long Bonds
item.description: Investors are jumping into longer-dated Colombia bonds, wagering that the market has overshot the risks associated with President Gustavo Petro’s budget woes.
item.dc:creator: Nicolle Yapur, Oscar Medina

media:content.media:description: Gustavo Petro

item.title: EY Accused of Negligence at £2 Billion Trial Over NMC Health
item.description: EY continued to audit NMC Health Plc despite suspicions that management withheld key documents that revealed its true debt position, lawyers for the collapsed firm argued at the start of a £2 billion ($2.7 billion) London trial.
item.dc:creator: Upmanyu Trivedi

media:content.media:description: LONDON, ENGLAND - OCTOBER 01: The Ernst & Young (EY) offices stand in 1 More London Riverside on October 1, 2018 in London, England. The government has called for a review of the British auditing industry after a series of scandals including the collapses of Carillion and BHS revealed serious failures in the auditing process. The 'Big Four' accounting firms, which are Deloitte, PwC, Ernst & Young (EY) and KPMG audit the large majority of the UK's largest listed companies. (Photo by Jack Taylor/Getty Images)

item.title: Some Retailers Will Need to Eat Cost of Tariffs, Says Cicarelli
item.description: Scot Ciccarelli, Truist Equity Research managing director, says some retailers will have to eat the cost of higher tariffs and try to keep prices low. Several retailers, including Lowe's Cos Inc., TJX Companies Inc., and Ralph Lauren, are expected to post weaker earnings due to tariff-fueled economic anxiety and consumer pullback. He speaks on "Bloomberg Surveillance." (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: KKR Targets £8 Billion Cut to Thames Water Debt in Recovery Plan
item.description: KKR & Co. aims to slash about £8 billion ($10.7 billion) of Thames Water’s debt as part of its plan to turn around the beleaguered British utility, according to people familiar with the matter.
item.dc:creator: Priscila Azevedo Rocha, Giulia Morpurgo

media:content.media:description: Thames Water signage explaining the nearby pipe replacement work being carried out, in London.

item.title: Blackstone Makes $5.7 Billion Bet on Power With Deal to Buy TXNM
item.description: Blackstone Infrastructure agreed to acquire New Mexico utility owner TXNM Energy Inc. for about $5.7 billion, the latest in a flurry of power deals as US electricity consumption grows.
item.dc:creator: Mark Chediak, Josh Saul, David Carnevali

media:content.media:description: The Blackstone headquarters in New York.

item.title: Giant Australia Pension Funds Grow to Eight in $2.7 Trillion Pot
item.description: Growth in Australia’s booming A$4.2 trillion ($2.7 trillion) pensions industry pushed another firm into the so-called mega fund category, a further sign of the country’s swelling retirement pot becoming dominated by the biggest players.
item.dc:creator: Amy Bainbridge

item.title: Romania Budget Woes Put Brakes on Post-Election Market Rally
item.description: Romania’s assets rallied after a centrist candidate defeated his nationalist opponent in the presidential election, but further market relief may be limited until the next government presents a plan to fix state finances.
item.dc:creator: Andra Timu, Peter Laca

media:content.media:description: A supporter holds a poster of Nicusor Dan in Bucharest, Romania, on May 18.
